entry.title: Suggestion: Link the linked accounts
entry.content:
(I tried to start this as a suggestion, but it seems I have no enough privileges, so I must bother you with a normal post)

So I had this account for years, since I fell in the SAP world circa 2004. It's linked to my personal e-mail account, and I want to keep it that way to preserve my sad and useless history of contributions here. Because it's a personal one, it's a P account. No problem with that.

But as I need to keep working with SAP, my company registered me another account linked to my company e-mail address. Because it's a professional one, and I assume my company pays for it somehow, it's an S account. Nice.

What's my problem? I join everyday here with my P account, I dig for info, and sometimes I find someone telling "check the XXXX note". So I go to me.sap.com to check that note and... I have no authorization there. I check my account info and I see both accounts linked, but the system is uncapable of decide that if I am in the support section, I must be treated as an S account, and treat me as a P account while in the community one.

So I must log out, log in again and keep doing that every day.

Please, try to change that behaviour to allow us with linked S&P accounts to be treated according to the section.

(it's curious how the post changed when I noticed "treat" comes without "h")

entry.title: Re: BAPI_ROUTING_CREATE
entry.content:
Hello there

Your code is rather difficult to read. Please do consider using the code sample formatting option.

There seem to be several issues here:

  •  The error itself means that you are missing links between the different internal tables, i.e. how these records belong together. The BAPI won't know, whether you want to create one routing for one material with several operations or several routings for several materials with one operation or what - unless you tell the BAPI exactly what to do. Which you can achieve by specifying GROUP_COUNTER in the relevant tables to establish the link between these records.
  • Based on your input data, it seems you want to create one routing for one material with 11 operations. Yet, you loop at your input data and create not only multiple it_op records, but also multiple it_task and it_mat_task_allo records
  • Lastly, perhaps it is just formatting, but based on your GUI_UPLOAD call, the input file should be TAB separated. This doesn't seem to be the case.

entry.title: Could an SAP SD career be a good choice for you?
entry.content:
Is becoming an SAP Sales and Distribution (SD) Consultant a good career choice? Short answer: Yes.

Longer answer:

The SD consultant manages the process from taking a customer order to getting paid (called Order-to-Cash). This job is highly demanded right now.

1.  Why is this job a good investment?

High Demand and Good Salary:

Migration Pressure: Only about 37% of SAP customers have moved to the new S/4HANA system. This means 63% still need to move. This huge amount of work means consultants are needed for many years to come, which keeps salaries high.  

2.  Is SAP SD the right module for you?

You should choose SD if you have experience or interest in: Sales, Logistics, Shipping, or Order Management. Success is about understanding the business, not just clicking buttons.  

Key skills to master:

You need the basics, plus these high-value skills in S/4HANA:

  • Pricing Procedures: You must know how to set up complex pricing rules. 
  • Integration: Know how SD connects with Finance (FI) and Inventory (MM).  
  • Advanced ATP (aATP): This is the new tool for checking stock availability. Master aATP to help clients manage product shortages and prioritize orders for important customers.  
  • FSCM Credit: SAP moved Credit Management to the Finance module. You must understand this new setup to integrate sales and finance properly.  

Advices for beginners:

Experience first: Most companies want consultants with 3–4 years of experience.  

Best starting path: If you don’t find your way to consultancy positions; Try to get a job as an SAP end-user in a related area (like Order Management) for 1–2 years. This gives you the real-world business knowledge that consultants need.  

Practice then Practice: You can get a free S/4HANA trial system, set up a pretend company, and practice the processes yourself. This is great for interviews.  

3.  The Future: AI and the SD Consultant

Will AI (like SAP Joule) take your job? No.

AI will automate many routine tasks, but it will not replace the consultant. AI will change your job to focus on higher value work:  

  • Less basic setup: AI helps with basic setup and testing tasks.  
  • More strategy: Your new role is to check the AI's work and focus on complex problems. You will also help clients use AI features (like predictive analytics) to make better decisions, such as optimizing their inventory levels.  
  • Clean Code: You must become an expert at reducing complex custom code inside the main system (this is called Clean Core) to make the system easier to update.  

The SAP SD career is a strong investment if you focus on the new S/4HANA specialties and you love it.

entry.title: How to handle rejected stock lots on EWM with HU
entry.content:
We need to bring back the restricted batch status to unrestricted batch status and the blocked stock to unrestricted stock type which has been already rejected by quality. Decentralized EWM, Pharma industry.

Business case

It is possible that after the batch is rejected, not all the quantity will share the same decision. Assuming we have 100 units rejected, maybe only 20 would be discarded, and 80 to be reprocessed or shipped to customer or whatever the decision may be. the decision can be done in parts. meaning today decision for 20 to be discarded. 1 month later, the decision for the reamining 80 to be reprocessed.

Also it is possible that some quantity is rejected, but the overall inspection lot is released. and the rejected HUs can have a different decision. Example. rejected 5 units out of 100 units. the 5 units that are rejected, 2 will be discarded, 3 will be use for other purpose. 

Pain point:

1. How to change the batch status for each lot quantity from same batch.
2. Changing the batch status will change the status for whole lot. How can we do it particularly for respective HU & Batch. Here the rework.
3. How to handle the Usage decision for rejected HU and batch as the decision will take a long while for different parts.
4. In EWM how the stock will be traced. We have 4 screnario where we can scrap, ship, rework, Reuse the rejected part.
5. How can we trace the rejected stock movements in EWM and S4. How to identify that is rejected stock and its be moved due to quality issue. both in shopfloor and SAP
6. If we are doing rework how to release the rejected batch and at the same time not to consider this for MRP and other process order.
7. If we are doing shipment how to consider the MPR and no consumption against other sale/delivery.
8. How the quality certificates will be traced for normal and rejected same batch lots.

Do combining quality notification, custom action box and quality task solve this problem.

entry.title: Actual Costing in S/4HANA – Single-Level Only Possible?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m currently working with a customer who is interested in using Actual Costing to improve their material valuation process.
The goal would be to post production variances directly to the material itself – similar to how purchase price differences are already included for raw materials – but without rolling them up through multiple BOM levels.

For example, the customer produces prefabricated components (“prefabs”) from raw materials.
Each prefab should reflect its own actual production and procurement variances, while higher-level assemblies that use these prefabs should be valuated at the current PUP (periodic unit price).

From what I remember, under ECC the process steps for Single-Level and Multilevel Valuation were executed separately during the Actual Costing run.
I’m not completely sure whether this setup actually allowed a single-level-only approach, but it looked like the logic could be separated.
In S/4HANA, these steps seem to have been merged into one single phase called Settlement.

My question is therefore:
Is there still a way in S/4HANA to perform only single-level valuation, so that variances are applied directly to the material without rolling them up to higher-level products?
Or is this no longer possible with the new Actual Costing design?

We use S/4HANA on premise 2023. 

Thanks in advance for any insights or experience!

Best regards,
Olga

entry.title: Auto Clearing of Invoices and Credit Memos in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
The client has requested auto clearing functionality in SAP Public Cloud to automatically clear invoices reference against credit memos when both have the same values.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Auto Clearing of Invoices and Credit Memos in SAP Pub...
entry.content:
SAP Public Cloud supports the automatic clearing of open items from customer, supplier and G/L accounts (in particular, GR/IR clearing accounts). It selects all accounts that are specified in the value sets and that have debit and credit postings.

 

In order to set up the clearing program to run automatically as scheduled, you will need to prepare 2 tasks.

  • First, you need to identify criteria for automatic clearing validation. In Manage Your Solution, follow SSCUI 101971 - Prepare Automatic Clearing to define criteria according to your requirements. Please note that up to five selections are supported for this configuration.
  • Second, you will schedule the clearing program to run automatically with Automatic Clearing app. According to your request, you will tick on "Select Customers" checkbox, and enter the list of customer number here for reconciliation, together with other parameters.

 

The remaining open items are grouped according to fixed system criteria:

  • Company code
  • Account type
  • Account number
  • Reconciliation account number
  • Currency key
    • BSID-WAERS for customers
    • BSIK-WAERS for suppliers
    • BSIS-PSWSL for G/L accounts
  • Special G/L indicator

 

Clearing only execute when the balance in document currency is zero for the group of customer line items selected according to the above criteria. 

Additionally, certain items are excluded from automatic clearing, such as:

  • Noted items
  • Statistical postings and special G/L transactions of the type bill of exchange
  • Items with withholding tax postings
  • Down payments, unless down payment clearing for the same amount has been posted

entry.title: End-to-End Shell Copy Scenario in Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM) 1.0
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Step 1: System Export
  • 1. Download the Latest SWPM:
  • 2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario
  • 3. Set Source System Parameters
  • 4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0
  • 5. Transfer Export Directory
  • Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host)
  • 1. Prepare Target Database
  • 2. Install ASCS Instance
  • 3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries
  • 4. Import Database Shell Instance
  • 5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS)
  • Step 3: Post-Copy Activities
  • Tips & Recommendations
  • Useful Links

 

Introduction

Shell Copy is a new scenario introduced in SWPM 1.0 to support digital transformation with SAP Business Transformation Center.  For more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC].  

The shell copy scenario helps you prepare an SAP ERP shell system containing all Dictionary and Repository objects and all Customizing - while excluding application data. For more insights, please see the introductory blog: [Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario]. 

Below, you'll find an example workflow that demonstrates a typical Shell Copy procedure using SWPM 1.0 for SAP ERP 6.0 EHP8 on Linux. The process consists of three main phases: system export, system provisioning, and post-copy steps.  

IMPORTANT: Always consult the latest SAP product documentation and Shell Copy Guide specific to your operating system and database platform. Review and apply all relevant SAP Notes before starting the Shell Copy scenario on your landscape. 

 

Step 1: System Export

1. Download the Latest SWPM:  
  • Obtain the latest SWPM 1.0 for NW higher than 7.0x SAR file supporting Shell Copy from SAP Software Center. 
  • Review prerequisites: "Running Software Provisioning Manager". 
2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario 
  • In the Product Catalog, select: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Source System → Database Instance Shell Export 

 

3. Set Source System Parameters 
  • Confirm or enter the path to the SAP ECC profile folder 

  • Enter <sid> adm password when prompted. 

 

  • Provide the DDIC user’s password in client 000 (needed for online preparation). 

4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0 
  • In the Shell Copy scenario, Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0 replaces Migration Monitor for database migration. 

  • Specify the export directory path where SWPM will extract and run SUM. 
  • Download and provide the latest SUM 2.0 archive from the SAP Software Center. 

  • Confirm the “Parameter Summary” dialog to trigger exports. 
5. Transfer Export Directory 
  • When export is completed, copy the entire export directory to the target host (including SUM and data). 

Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host) 

1. Prepare Target Database 
  • Set up the target database per the installation guide for SAP ERP 6.0. Under “Product Release”, make sure that you select “SAP NetWeaver 7XX-based”. 
  • Tip: Review and apply required SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
    that resolve known issues. 
2. Install ASCS Instance 
  • Start SWPM 1.0 on the target and choose: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Target System → ASCS Instance 
  • The SAP system ID (SAPSID) must remain the same between source and target (e.g., if source is SC1, target must also be SC1). 
  • In that example we provide a Master Password for all system users such, e.g. <sid>adm, SAPService<SAPSID>. If you did not create the operating system users manually before the installation, the Software Provisioning Manager creates them with the common Master Password. If users are not pre-created, SWPM will create them. 
  • For master password requirements, refer to he SAP System Parameters section of the installation guide. 
3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries 
  • SWPM will prompt for SAPEXE Kernel archive and the SAP Host Agent binary files - have them ready. 
4. Import Database Shell Instance 
  • On the target DB host, launch SWPM and select: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Target System → Database Shell Instance 
  • For standard installation (all instances on one host), /sapmnt/ is local and SWPM will detect profile directory. 
  • Use the previously set master password and <sid>adm password 
  • Enter the same DBSID as used in the source system.
  • Provide the required SAP Kernel resources
  • Specify the SUM export directory path you copied earlier. 
  • Note: If changing CPU architecture (e.g., Windows to Linux), provide the appropriate SUM.SAR for the new OS on the target system

  • Address any DB-specific dialogs without making unsupported changes to the DB layer. 
5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS) 
  • Launch SWPM and choose: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Target System → Stub Primary Application Server Instance 
  • Specify the instance profile folder. 
  • Use the previously set master password. 
  • Provide archives for SAPEXE, IGSEXE, and IGSHelper as requested. 
  • Address any DB-specific dialogs. 
  • Once the PAS instance installation has been completed, the Shell ABAP system should be up and running. 

Step 3: Post-Copy Activities 

The last step is to prepare the Shell ERP system as described in the Follow-Up Activities section of the Shell Copy Guide for your operating system and platform. 

Tips & Recommendations 
  • Prepare required SAP Notes in advance to avoid interruptions. 
  • Use the latest supported versions of SWPM and SUM. 
  • Avoid DB layer changes between source and target unless explicitly supported by SAP. 
  • Master passwords should comply with all OS-level security policies. 
Useful Links 
  • SAP Software Center 
  • Shell Copy Guide 
  • Post-Copy Activities 
  • SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
  • “Reducing DB Size of SAP ERP systems via Shell Copy Scenario” 

By following these steps, you can efficiently perform a shell copy of your SAP ERP landscape using SWPM 1.0 and SUM 2.0.

entry.title: Re: 查看Customer Insights Dashboard报告的权限
entry.content:
Hi Jimmy,

若要查看您截图中提供的卡片，您的 S-user 需具备「Display Support Situation Reporting」权限。
 
您可通过以下两种方式获取该权限：
  1. 登录 SAP for Me 的 S-User Management - SAP for Me，联系任意管理员为您添加权限
  2. 通过自助申请获取，参考 SAP KBA 2891528 - How to use the Self-Service Authorization Request - SAP for Me
成功添加权限后，您可查看的内容包括：
  • 购买的产品（按类别）
  • 许可证使用率指标
  • 云功能使用情况（近 6 个月）
关于Customer Insights Dashboard 的访问方法以及所需权限，可参考 SAP KBA 3336856 - How to access Customer Insights Dashboard - SAP for Me

祝顺商祺!

SAP Support

entry.title: Info/Links for TechEd Community Talk CT1293 - SAP Build Control Tower
entry.content:
This post is to provide additional reference information and links related to my community talk CT1293 - Get control of the control tower feature in SAP Build solutions. See you there.

Control Tower Layout

Here's is the current picture of the Control Tower.

I think the layout is simple and clean, though it has evolved with additional tiles over the last 2 years and I don't think it's so clear how everything is inter-related. Here is my annotated version with a few notes. 

My notes:

  • Environments, introduced relatively recently with the public environment deprecated, seems to me the central most-important tile on the page
  • Destinations and API keys are strongly connected to environments
  • The first 3 tiles are related to transport: The first defines whether the tenant is dev/qa/prod for the sake of transport, and the governance rules (next 2 tiles) in part add an extra layer of approval for transport operations. The rules also affect simply creating a project.

More information on the Control Tower: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-control-tower?locale=en-US

Permissions

There are many layers of permissions within SAP Build. Here they are from highest to lowest level.

IAS

Identity Authentication Service (IAS), or perhaps now just Cloud Identity Service, is the very first level and at the most basic level lets you create new users.

I just want to point out one helpful feature are groups. I can set up a group and then assign that group role connections. When I have a new user I just add them to the group and they inherent all the role collections. 

Here are groups in IAS.

Here I assign a group to a role collection. Note that SAP BTP does not have a dropdown of groups so you have to simply type in the name of the group.

YOu can do the same with attributes, for example, assign a role collection based on job function or home country.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/landing-page?locale=en-US

Tenants

Once you have a user in IAS, you can assign that user to a tenant and NOT assign them to other tenants. You can look in the Users page to see which users have access to the current tenant.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/business-users?locale=en-US

Roles

Once a user has access to the tenant in some way, you determine what they can do on that tenant by assigning them roles, not directly, but through role collections, which are sets of roles that loosely map to a persona (e.g., admin, developer, business user, super user).

Here's more information on the specific roles/role collections related to the low-code tools of SAP Build:

  • SAP Build Apps: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-apps/service-guide/configuring-user-roles?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Process Automation: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/authorizations?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Work Zone: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/about-roles-and-role-assignments?locale=en-US&q=role

Design-Time Authorizations

These authorizations are done on the project level, some know as collaboration authorizations, so you can work with others on specific projects.

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-project-members?locale=en-US.

Runtime Automarizations

Runtime authorizations are the authorizations you have within environments. Environments are separate areas for deploying projects, and each environment can be set up to allow different users to do different activities (e.g., view, deploy, add users).

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/share-environment.

Governance Rules

Governance rules let you set up a process to be executed so managers can approve or reject whether another user can create a project or transport a project.

If you enable rules for either creation or transport, you are automatically given into the lobby an out-of-the-box process and action. You must deploy the process before the rules can take effect (the action is automatically published). Before deploying, you can modify the process -- you really must since it the process automatically gives the requestor the right to approve his own project.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/governance?locale=en-US&q=governance+rules.

Transport

Transport allows you to create formal processes for moving projects from one tenant to another tenant, generally from DEV > QA > PROD. The transport does not deploy projects but simply moves the design-time projects from one SAP Build installation to another. You can only transport a released version.

You will have to install Cloud Transport Manager Service, and add the Content Agent Service on every tenant to which you want to transport content. 

Once you have everything setup and execute a transport from the SAP Build lobby, the package goes to CTMS, where someone with the import role will need to approve the transport. 

For more information on setting up transport, see https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/transporting-content-in-sap-build-apps-sap-cloud-transport-management/ba-p/13737478.

For more information on how to transport and prerequisites, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/transport-project?locale=en-US&q=transport.

entry.title: Re: What is the difference in use of &variable and variab...
entry.content:
Hello,

the difference is where you read the value of that wage type:

  1.  With AMT=& 9001, you read the amount of variable 9001 in the VAR  table (Variable table) that is a temporary table created during the payroll processing. But to use it, before you should fill the table with ADDWT&9001 operation.
  2. With AMT=  9000, you read the amount of wage type 9001 in the IT (Input Table) table

In conclusion, the VAR table is a variable table that stores user-defined variables (and not wage type) during payroll processing. It serves as a temporary storage mechanism for calculations and data manipulation within payroll control records (PCRs).  

Hope I clarified your doubts.

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: Re: SAP CC, 5M rows Soft limit includes Catalog and Subsc...
entry.content:
Hello,

indeed, according to the SAP note 2478958 - Impact of the Master Data on the SAP CC Performance , the Catalog Mapping table has soft limit of 5M rows in system. This is only for catalog mapping table. 

There is not soft limit for the total number of row of the subscriber mapping table.  There is a limit of row for a single subscriber mapping table but not for the total in the system. Nevertheless, the limit will be in the DB capacity to store the total. 

Best regards,
Eric F.

entry.title: Re: Update Charge Plan Parameter Values during Usage Events
entry.content:
Hello Xhoi,
you can store the value of a date in a counter in order to implement your requirement. To do that,  use the Property Type Convertor and convert the date in a number by selecting "Milliseconds since 1970" as field to use.  Set the counter with the computed value.
Then, to read the date, you create a date property to 1st of January 1970 (Property Introducer) and you add the counter value to this date (Date Shift) by using seconds for the "Duration Unit". 
I don't have any bypass for the string property. 

Best regards,

Eric F.

entry.title: Re: SAP Implementation Consultant: Guidance for Beginner
entry.content:
Spoiler
That’s a great question — and one many people ask when they start their SAP journey.

Start by building HR process knowledge first — hiring, time, payroll — then move into SAP HCM configuration (PA, OM, TM, PY) to understand how HR logic is modeled in the system.

Next, transition to SAP SuccessFactors (Employee Central, Time Off, Time Tracking) — this is where the market is heading. Follow the SAP Learning Journeys, practice in sandbox/demo tenants, and document your configurations as if you were delivering a customer workbook.

Learn the SAP Activate methodology — Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy — to understand how real implementations are structured.

Finally, stay current with 2 cycle releases, engage in the SAP Community, and focus on practical scenarios

In short:
HR foundation → SAP HCM core → SuccessFactors EC → Activate methodology → Practice & Community → Continuous learning.

entry.title: Re: With reference to PO how to create auto GRN using bac...
entry.content:
You can automate Goods Receipt (GR) posting from Purchase Orders in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using released APIs or RAP-based background jobs, but this approach carries high operational risk and must be carefully evaluated.

Automating GR without human validation introduces several risks:

Incorrect Postings: If PO quantities or delivery status are not accurately validated, it can lead to over-receipts or duplicate GRs.

Error Recovery: Failed or incorrect GRs can be difficult to reverse, especially in Public Cloud where transaction control is limited.

Limited Monitoring: Standard SAP tools may not provide granular logs for custom GR jobs, making troubleshooting harder.

So, I strongly recommend that if automation is pursued, ensure robust validation logic, error handling, and audit trails are built into the solution. Consider starting with a pilot for low-risk materials or vendors.

entry.title: Re: Manage Teams and Responsibilities versions
entry.content:
Good day @zeytin 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Working with Fiori Apps.

To summarise, your observation is correct. The app (Manage Teams and Responsibilities) technically belongs to the public cloud library, but it becomes available in private cloud when the corresponding business role (with the same OData service) is activated. The reason could be because:

  • Both editions run on the same ABAP cloud stack.
  • There are some cross-edition Fiori applications that are embedded in both system types but are restricted by configuration and authorisation.
  • When you activate the Resource Scheduling role, due to its OData service and UI5 component reference, it can expose the public cloud app shell even in a private cloud environment.

Note there is a slight name difference for public cloud (see attached screenshot) when you search for Manage Teams and Responsibilities. The system does not present the option “Manage Teams and Responsibilities for Maintenance” as you can see in your (attached screenshot) private cloud search. It is not a malfunction, rather it is due to SAP’s unified Fiori app architecture that reuses front-end components across editions.

So, in your case, even though your system is Private Cloud, activating that business catalog triggered the Fiori tile to appear.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
Hi,

It seems you want to display the gross amount per order, with the option for the user to add the item number as an additional dimension for deeper insights. The downside to this approach is that you won't be able to get a total value at the end, which would otherwise match the value shown in 'Item Gross Amount.'

entry.title: Re: Company code currency change
entry.content:
Hello Zuzana,

if there are already postings existing for the set of books assigned to the company, it is not ppossible to change the currency of the Set of books.

Hence you would need to create a new company in ByD, Assign Set of books ( with the required currency) and then migrate the data from old company ( with HUF Currency) to New company (with EUR currency).

you can also assign multiple set of books to one company (Probabaly with the same charts of Account, if you use different chart of accounts and Account determination profile, GLs could be different, if you use same Charts of account and Account determinationg group then you can arrive at the same GLs but with different currencies i.e parallel bookings for each currency in their respective set of books) but with different currency.
Example : Set of books 1 : HUF, Set of books 2 : EUR.
hence when the postings are made for the documents (Customer invoice, Supplier invoice etc), system will create the Journal entries in both the books at the same time, using the Chart of accounts and Account determination profiles set up.
Postings in Set of book 1 will be in HUF and in Set of books 2 will be in EUR.

So if you book the invoice in EUR, in Set of books 1, it will be converted to HUF using the exchange rate and corresponding rate will be displayed in journal Entry. In set of books 2, posting will be made with EUR and here no exchange rate will be used and will not be displayed.

if you book the invocie in HUF, in Set of books 1, posting will be made with HUF and here no exchange rate will be used and will not be displayed. In set of books 2, it will be converted to EUR using the exchange rate and corresponding rate will be displayed in journal Entry.


Other point to consider is,
if you book the invoice in EUR (Also Set of books currency), and Invoice is booked with the tax country Hungary, system will still calculate the Tax Amounts in HUF using exchange rate for the internal Calculation and tax reporting purposes. this you can extract using the reports / and should be also visible in the journal Entry ( but only for the relevant tax line item of the posting). however in this case, AP/ AR other GLs / Sub ledger will not be converted to HUF currency. Only Tax line is converted to HUF currency.



Hope this helps.

Harshal

entry.title: ByDesign 2511 Release: New Built-in Support User Guide - Beta Version
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide is designed to help Key Users of SAP Business ByDesign transition to the new Built-In Support (BIS). It covers the prerequisites and the process for creating cases using the new BIS after moving away from the existing Business ByDesign Built-In Support.

      Current Built-In Support (BIS) Behavior

  • End users and Key users currently log cases through ByD BIS by navigating to Help Center > Report a Case.
  • When necessary, key users can forward cases to SAP using the Forward to Provider option.

       New Built-In Support (BIS) Behavior

  • End users will continue to report cases to key users by navigating to the Help Center and selecting Solve an Issue or Report a Case.
  • If a Key User needs to send a case to SAP, they must create and manage the case directly within the new BIS system.
  • The New BIS will fully replace the existing Built-In Support in upcoming releases.

The diagram below illustrates the removal of the existing Built-In Support and its replacement with the New BIS.

Scope

This document is intended for Key Users involved in case management. It provides guidance on how to effectively utilize the new Built-In Support (BIS) features and outlines the procedure for requesting additional BIS functionality.

Note: The new BIS tool is available only for Key Users. End Users will not have access to this tool, and there are no changes to their current experience.

Pre-requisites and procedure for activating new BIS features

Prerequisites for Using the New BIS

  • You must be a Key User and have a valid S-user ID with case management authorization for the SAP Business ByDesign product.
  • After signing in with your S-user ID, you will gain access to the additional support features of the new Built-In Support.
  • For detailed login instructions, refer to the relevant KBA 3650332.

Procedure to Enable the new BIS Feature in SAP Business ByDesign (Beta Version 2511)

  • Create a case- Submit a case to SAP Support with your tenant details, where it should be activated.
  • Customer Consent- SAP will initiate a Test Evaluation Agreement (TEA) document for customer approval. This step is mandatory as per SAP’s process for enabling beta features.
  • Feature Activation- Once TEA is completed, SAP will enable the new Built-In Support (BIS) functionality from the backend.

Note:

  • The new BIS functionality is currently available as a Beta Release in version 2511.
  • It cannot be enabled in production tenants and is restricted to test tenants only.
  • For more details on onboarding, refer to KBA 3650332 - Onboarding ByD Customers Into new Built-In Support

Process Steps

The following are the steps to launch a new BIS tool from ByD and create a case for SAP.

  • Launch new BIS tool

Choose the Built-In Support headset icon in the shell bar of your ByD system,

  • Login to new BIS Tool

 Login to new BIS by clicking “Sign-In” button

`

Enter your S-User ID and Password credentials as shown below. For detailed instructions, refer to Signing In with Your S-user ID help documentation.

Note: Refer to additional KBA in case of S-User ID authentication issues.
KBA 3584368 - Updates to key user login process due to identity management changes - Built-In Support
2371719 - S-user ID login error: Sorry, we could not authenticate you. Try again. - SAP for Me

  • After you signed in successfully, follow the KBA 3000949 - How to create a support case - Built-In Support.

Limitations

  • New Built-In Support is not available to all tenants hosted in the China region data center due to legal compliance.
  • External reference ID will be irrelevant when a tenant is migrated to new Built-In Support.
  • Once new Built-In support is enabled, there is no fallback to old ByD Built-in support.
  • Customer Help Desk (CHD) or Customer Competence Center (CCC), or Partner Scenario
    • Tickets can only be forwarded either from the Central Key User or from a partner tenant using the new BIS.
    • If a partner setup is connected to the CHD server tenant (central Key User tenant), and a Central Key User has already forwarded a case to the Partner, they should not forward the same case again through the new BIS to avoid duplicate case submissions to SAP.
      Note: KBA 2611988 - To know more about the CCC and CHD Process.
      Partner Scenario - Customer case handling by partner.       
  • There is no automatic synchronization for older cases with the new BIS. Since the Forward to Provider option is disabled, you can only contact SAP through the new BIS. For existing tickets, you can update them directly in SAP for Me.
    For more details, refer to 3665054 - How to Find and Process, in SAP for Me, Cases created from a ByD or C4C tenant.

 

Additional References

  • Built-In Support | User Guide for Key Users
  • 3052441 - What is SAP's Built-In Support?
  • 3000949 - How to create a support case – Built-In Support
  • 3665054 - How to Find and Process, in SAP for Me, Cases created from a ByD or C4C tenant.
  • KBA 2611988 - To know more about CCC and CHD Process.
  • KBA 3584368 - Updates to key user login process due to identity management changes - Built-In Support
  • 2371719 - S-user ID login error: Sorry, we could not authenticate you. Try again. - SAP for Me
  • KBA 3650332 - Onboarding ByD Customers Into new Built-In Support

entry.title: ByDesign 2511 Release: Introducing Attachment Extraction (Controlled Availability)
entry.content:
Introduction 

As per the contract, SAP is required to share customer data stored in Business ByDesign (ByD) upon request or when the system reaches its end of lifecycle. This document is intended for business users involved in the data extraction process from ByD. It provides detailed, step-by-step guidance on the initial setup and the procedure to extract data from ByD and transfer it to SAP-managed SharePoint.

 

Scope  

The scope of this document is limited to business users who are involved in the extraction process using this feature.

Attachment Extraction Process

Customers who want to extract tenant-specific attachments using this self-service feature can raise a request to SAP via a case. SAP will perform the initial setup and enable the feature for self-service use. Once enabled, users can follow the steps outlined in this document to extract the files. After the extraction is complete, the files should be moved from the SAP-managed SharePoint to the required storage location.

Information to Provide when Creating a Case with SAP

  • Tenant details from which the extraction needs to be performed
  • Email IDs of the SharePoint folder consumers

Step-By-Step Process 

This is a Two-Step Process

  1. Attachment Preparation Run – The attachment-related data is prepared and stored in an intermediate staging area.
  2. Attachment Extraction Run – Attachments for the selected Business Object (BO) and date are retrieved from the staging area and extracted to SharePoint.

Feature 

Details 

Attachment Preparation Run 

Create/Manage Runs to prepare the attachment data to the staging area. 

Attachment Overview 

The staged records can be viewed at the overview screen. The failed/selected records can be included for the re-run by resetting the status to ‘Pending’ 

Attachment Extraction Run 

Once the data is staged, the files are now ready to be extracted to SharePoint. Create a Run by giving a BO name and date. The attachments for the given BO documents and date will be extracted to SharePoint. 

Below are the steps explaining the entire process.

  1. Attachment Preparation Run 

Go to Application and User Management -> Attachment Extraction -> Attachment Preparation Run. 

Click on New -> Attachment Preparation run 

Create a Run by providing the details below 

  • Run ID 
  • Run Description 
  • Choose the relevant Document Type:
    • Attachment – For extracting documents from attachments  
    • Output History – For extracting documents from Output History 
  • Select Application Log Content as desired. 
  • Click on Add Row and select the desired Business object from the drop down. 
  • Use action Clear – To clear the given inputs in case you want to switch to a different document type. 

Click on Save -> Select Set to Active -> And then Schedule it

Once the activated run is executed successfully, the attachment data will be stored in the staging area.

Attachment Overview screen 

Go to Application and User Management -> Attachment Extraction -> Attachment Overview.  

The documents will initially be in pending status. 

Select any document to enable the buttons ‘Reset Status’ and ‘Reset All’. 

Reset Status: This button resets the selected document status to ‘Pending’ (Including the completed documents, if selected).   

Reset All: This button will reset all the failed statuses of the documents to Pending (Including the documents with failed statuses that are not shown on the screen). 

  1. Attachment Extraction Run

Go to Application and User Management -> Attachment Extraction -> Attachment Extraction Run  

Click on New.

Provide below details 

  • Run ID 
  • Run Description 
  • Choose relevant Document Type
  • Select Application Log Content as desired. 
  • Creation date is optional 
  • Click on Add Row and select Business object from the drop-down. 
  • Click on Save -> Select Set to Active -> and then Schedule it.

After the run is successfully executed, navigate to the Attachment Overview screen and search for the relevant business object. The processing status should display “Completed” for successfully extracted documents. If the extraction to SharePoint fails, the status will show as “Failed.” In case of a failed status, you can reset the status and re-execute the run.

Now, go to the SharePoint link provided in the case and look for the relevant files and folders. 

Do’s

  • Grant SharePoint access beforehand, prior to extraction. When a SharePoint site exceeds 50,000 files, Manage Access cannot be used.
  •  Download smaller folders after extraction instead of large ones.
  •  Clean up the folder/files once they are downloaded to your desired locations
  •  Complete extraction and move files to the desired storage within 15 days (retention period).
  •  Be aware that special characters like :, /, \ in folder or file names are automatically replaced with _ to ensure supportability in the download. (example: Testfile/01:2025.PDF, will be replaced as Testfile_01_2025).

 Dont’s

  • Do not run parallel jobs, as this can cause excessive memory consumption and job failure.
  • The process supports extracting all BOs, but the same memory and runtime limitations apply.
  • Do not change folder names or modify folders in SharePoint — it can break the API path and cause process failure.
  • Avoid continuous extraction without cleanup — it can overconsume site capacity.

 Best Practices 

  • Use the   option to keep folders up to date with your local drive or OneDrive.
  • Extract each Business Object (BO) separately and clean up the folder after completing the extraction.

entry.title: How I Prepared for SAP C_AIG_2412 (AI Foundation) – A Practical Approach That Actually Works ?
entry.content:
Hey everyone,

I recently completed my preparation for the SAP Certified Application Associate – SAP AI Foundation (C_AIG_2412) exam, and I wanted to share my approach and what really helped me along the way. I saw many threads here about the best way to study or what topics to focus on, so here’s a concise, experience-based breakdown that might help others too.

🧩 Problem: Where to Begin?

When I first started, the biggest challenge was understanding what’s actually expected in the C_AIG_2412 exam. The official SAP Learning Hub has great material, but I found it a bit scattered for someone trying to build a full picture of AI within SAP BTP and AI Launchpad.

✅ My Solution:

Here’s how I structured my preparation in 3 phases:

1️⃣ Phase One – Foundation (Understanding the Ecosystem):
I began with SAP’s official Learning Journey for AI Foundation. It helped me understand the integration of SAP AI Core, AI Launchpad, and AI lifecycle management. I noted down key features like model deployment, governance, and responsible AI use.

2️⃣ Phase Two – Hands-On Practice:
Theory alone wasn’t enough. I used the SAP BTP Trial Account to deploy a small AI scenario using SAP AI Core. This gave me a strong grip on the workflow and terminology that appear in the exam.

3️⃣ Phase Three – Practice Questions & Gap Fixing:
In this stage, I started practicing using C_AIG_2412 dumps and practice tests from MyCertsHub
. What I liked was that the practice material reflected real-world exam logic—not just memorization, but scenario-based questions on AI lifecycle, data pipelines, and AI Launchpad management.
I used these practice questions to identify weak areas and went back to the SAP documentation to fill the gaps.

🔍 Key Exam Areas I Encountered:

Understanding SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad

Managing AI models and pipelines within SAP BTP

Applying Responsible AI principles

AI Governance and Monitoring

Integration with SAP Data Intelligence

🧠 Pro Tip:

Don’t skip hands-on practice. Even a small deployment scenario will make the architecture questions much easier to understand.
Also, go through MyCertsHub practice tests right before the exam—they simulate timing pressure and question patterns very closely to what I faced.

📘 Final Thoughts:

The C_AIG_2412 certification isn’t just about memorizing content—it’s about understanding how SAP embeds AI into its ecosystem responsibly and efficiently. If you follow structured learning, do some real practice, and test yourself with authentic resources, you’ll pass confidently.

Hope this helps others preparing for the exam!
Would love to hear how others are approaching the AI Foundation certification in 2025.

entry.title: BAdI that allows modification of standard fields in the production order header
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we would like to modify the order header information in the production order at the time of release, in our case, to indicate the batch at the header level that we want to use. We do not want to create a new batch, we want to automatically indicate an existing batch.

We have only found Badis that allow us to modify custom fields but not standard fields.

There is the BAdI BD_MFGORDER_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE, but it only allows checks to be performed.In SAP S/4HANNA On premise, we have the BAdI WORKORDER_UPDATE, which allows logic to be added to the production order.

Is there a BAdI that allows us to define logic for the information specified in the standard fields of the production order header?

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Payment media file format acceptable in Malaysia loca...
entry.content:
Good day @S0027169027 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Payment Medium Format, Payment Medium Workbench, Malaysia, Processing Payment Files

Configuration for Payment Processing

To summarise, in public cloud, Malaysia-specific and cross-border payments are supporting using predefined payment medium formats configured under country/region: MY. These formats can be generated using the “Manage Payment Media” app and manually uploaded to your local or foreign bank’s online banking portal.

Below is a detailed description on where to generate the file.

Search for Manage Payment Media

--> Filter by Payment Run Date or House Bank Account --> Locate the payment batch you want to extract.

Click the download File icon. The system generates the file based on the payment method and assigned format. Save the file locally and upload it to your bank portal.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: What's New in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hello Community,

On 29th Oct, 2025 several new features were released in SAP Cloud ALM product.

  • New supported data center (SAP Cloud ALM is now available in the region China: North 3)
  • New column for Library Type - Development
  • Drag and drop external files to upload
  • New Risks card in project overview
  • Relations are grouped in a single tab
  • Create test cases for solution process entities
  • Programs for project grouping
  • New language selection for SAP Assessment Service
  • Event actions for past events

and many more...

Check out this link -->What's New-CALM 

The feature which i like the most is as below :

Extensions are now classified into four levels (A to D), with Level A representing the best practices and Level D indicating those needing the most attention. This approach appreciates the value of both legacy code and new extensions built on classic frameworks, while aiming to decouple extensions, preferably through SAP-released APIs.

 

Happy reading and explore the power of SAP Cloud ALM!!!

Regards

Shubham

entry.title: Re: Issue with Liquidity Forecast View in Cash Flow Analy...
entry.content:
Hello @Vindhya 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Cash Flow Analyzer, Liquidity Planning with SAP Analytics Cloud, Cash Flow Analyzer

To summarise, the reason your Liquidity Forecast view shows only actual values is because the forecast data extraction hasn’t been executed or liquidity item assignments are missing. To enable it:

  • Run the Schedule Cash Flow Analyzer Data Extraction app.
  • Ensure liquidity items are properly assigned to open transactions.
  • Re-run the extraction and refresh the Liquidity Forecast view in Cash Flow Analyzer.

Once, configured, the forecast tab will show predicted cash inflows/outflows per liquidity item, complementing your actual cash flows.

Here is detailed process on how to activate forecast data extraction.

Search for Cash Flow Analyzer

Create a new extraction run. Schedule it to run “For All Dates” or up to the horizon you want to forecast. Execute or schedule it daily. This populates the forecast table.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: 🚀 Cost-Based PoC for Service Contracts – Expanded Support for Service Items
entry.content:
Co-Authored by Frank Hennrich and Volkmar Zahn  

We’re excited to announce a powerful enhancement coming with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS 0: support for cost-based percentage of completion (POC) revenue recognition for service contracts that include not only execution order items, but now also service items, expense items, service part items and tool items.

This enhancement brings greater flexibility and financial transparency to service contract management, enabling more accurate revenue recognition and reporting across a broader range of item types.

🌟 What’s New?

Until now, cost-based POC for service contracts was only available for assigned execution order items. With this update, you can now assign service order items with the following item types to a cost-based POC service contract item:

  • Service items
  • Expense items
  • Service part items
  • Tool items

These items can now contribute to the financial performance of the contract, enabling a more comprehensive and realistic view of project progress and profitability.

You can find more information about the new feature in Event-Based Revenue Recognition for Service Contracts as Root Items in Financial Hierarchy | SAP Help.

🧩 Key Configuration: Financial Hierarchy Root Item

To enable this functionality, the service contract item must be configured as a root item in the financial hierarchy. This is done by selecting the appropriate item category used during contract creation. If this checkbox is not set, the system will default to traditional time-based revenue recognition.

Once configured, the service contract item becomes the anchor for financial aggregation, allowing all assigned items to contribute to planned and actual values on contract item level.

🔍 How It Works

Let us look at a use case scenario of an IT Infrastructure Maintenance Contract

An IT service provider enters into a 24-month service contract with a large enterprise client to maintain their data center infrastructure. The contract includes:

  • Service Contract Item: Covers the commercial side of the overall infrastructure maintenance.
  • Service Order Items: Represent specific maintenance tasks (e.g., Routine server check, Security patching).

Revenue Recognition Logic: Cost-Based Percentage of Completion (PoC) method is used.

Planned Revenue: Taken from the service contract item (2000 USD)

Planned Cost: Aggregated from all service orders linked to service contract items.

This scenario highlights how hierarchical cost aggregation enables accurate cost-based revenue recognition in service contracts by aligning planned revenue from billable items with actual costs from maintenance activities.

 1. Create a Service Contract Item

Define the item as a financial hierarchy root by utilizing the corresponding item category. This enables it to collect financial data from all assigned items.

2. Assign Service Contract Item to Service Order Items
You can now assign the service contract item not only to execution order items but also service items, expense items, service part items, and tool items.

3. Plan and Track Costs and Revenues
For example, a service order item with a planned cost of 1232 USD ...

... and the planned revenue of 2000 USD from the service contract item ... 

... will now be included in the contract’s financial plan.

Upon release and service confirmation, actual costs and revenues are posted and recognized in real time.

4. Real-Time Revenue Recognition
Based on the cost-based POC method, revenue is recognized proportionally as actual costs are incurred, providing a more accurate reflection of project progress.

5. Enhanced Reporting
Reporting at the contract item level is now fully supported. Using familiar apps like Service Actuals, Product and Service Margins and Service Plan/Actuals, you can view both planned and actual values from the contract and all its assigned items—offering a complete financial picture.

📈 Why This Matters

This enhancement empowers service organizations to:

  • Improve financial accuracy and compliance
  • Gain deeper insights into contract performance
  • Streamline revenue recognition processes
  • Support more complex service delivery models

We’re thrilled to bring this capability to our customers and partners, helping you manage service contracts with greater precision and confidence.

💬 Have questions or want to share feedback? Join the conversation in our community forums!

entry.title: New Feature: Outbound Communication System Determination in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
• Overview
  • New UI: Communication System Determination
  • Create Determination Rules
  • Restrictions
  • Rule Configuration Options
  • Deletion
  • Multicast Behavior
  • Use cases for Outbound Communication System Determination
  • Sales Cloud Use Cases
  • Customer Service Use Cases
  • Enterprise Service Management (ESM) Use Cases
  • Outbound Configurations Supporting System Determination*
  • Watch: Configuring Outbound System Determinations

 

In SAP Sales & Service Cloud V1 (C4C), receiver determination for outbound messages was primarily handled using BADIs (Business Add-Ins). These BADIs allowed custom logic to route messages for instance to the correct ERP backend, such as SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP, based on attributes like Sales Organization. While effective, this approach required technical development and lacked a dedicated UI for business users to manage rules easily.

 

Overview 

For SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2, a new feature, Outbound Communication System Determination has been introduced. This enhancement enables businesses to dynamically determine the receiver system for outbound messages based on configurable logic and entity attributes. 

For example, Business Partner or Functional Location can be replicated from ESM to specific S/4HANA tenants based on organisation structure or service area. This ensures seamless integration and greater flexibility for multi-system landscapes.

 

New UI: Communication System Determination 

A dedicated UI has been added under Settings titled Communication System Determination, providing a centralised place to manage determination rules.

 

Create Determination Rules 

Rule creation is a two-step process: 

  1. Create Communication System Determination
    Select a Type (Message) and an Outbound Configuration. 
  2. Add Rules 
    Under each determination, create one or more rules. 

Restrictions 

  • Only one determination per unique Type + Outbound Configuration can be added. 
  • For each determination, only one rule can be active at a time. 
  • A determination is active if it has an active rule. 
  • Activating a new rule automatically deactivates the previous active rule. 
  • Each rule must have at least one condition block.  

Rule Configuration Options 

  • Add condition blocks with multiple conditions (business expressions). 
  • Assign one, multiple, or all communication systems to each block. 
  • Add a Default block with only communication systems (no conditions). 

Deletion 

  • Delete rules under a determination. 
  • Delete entire determinations when no longer needed. 

Multicast Behavior  

For some outbound configurations, sending a message to multiple systems is not supported. 

  • All condition groups (except for Default) are evaluated together. 
  • Communication systems from groups that evaluate to true are selected for sending the message. 
  • Important: For outbound configurations where multicast is not supported if multiple condition groups evaluate true, the message will not be sent. 

 

Use cases for Outbound Communication System Determination 

Sales Cloud Use Cases 

  1. Sales Quote Routing Based on Sales OrganizationScenario: A sales quote created in Sales Cloud must be sent to the appropriate S/4HANA or ERP system based on the Sales Org. 
    Example: Quotes for Sales Org 1000 route to S/4HANA Tenant A; Sales Org 2000 route to ERP Tenant B.
     
  2. Order Replication for Multi-ERP Landscapes
    Scenario: Customer orders created in Sales Cloud need to be replicated to different ERP systems depending on distribution channel or division. 
    Example: Orders for digital channels go to S/4HANA; traditional retail orders go to SAP ERP. 
     
  3. Pricing Requests
    Scenario: When a quote requires pricing, the request should be sent to the correct backend system based on product category or region. 
    Example: High-tech products route to S/4HANA for advanced pricing; commodity products route to ERP. 
     
  4. Contract Creation
    Scenario: Sales contracts initiated in Sales Cloud must be replicated to the correct ERP system based on company code or customer group. 
    Example: Strategic accounts route to S/4HANA; legacy accounts route to ERP. 

  5. Multicast for Shared Product Catalog
    Scenario: Updates to product master data from Sales Cloud need to be sent to multiple ERP systems managing different regions. 
    Example: A global product update replicates to both S/4HANA and ERP tenants simultaneously.  


Customer Service Use Cases 

  1. Case Routing
    Scenario: A customer service case created in SAP Service Cloud needs to be replicated to the correct S/4HANA tenant based on the service organization or region. 
    Example: Cases for North America route to S/4HANA Tenant A, while cases for Europe route to Tenant B.
          
  2. Warranty Claim Processing
    Scenario: Warranty claims initiated in Service Cloud must be sent to the ERP system managing warranty contracts. 
    Logic: Determine the communication system based on product category or contract type. 
    Example: High-value equipment claims go to S/4HANA for advanced processing; standard claims go to legacy ERP.
     
  3. Field Service Integration
    Scenario: Service orders created for on-site repairs need to be replicated to the correct backend for resource planning. 
    Logic: Use functional location or installed base attributes to select the right S/4HANA tenant. 
    Example: Locations tied to Plant 1000 route to Tenant A; Plant 2000 routes to Tenant B.
     

Enterprise Service Management (ESM) Use Cases 

  1. Master Data Replication
    Scenario: Business Partner or Functional Location replication from ESM to multiple S/4HANA tenants. 
    Logic: Determine target system based on organization structure or service area. 
    Example: Partners linked to Shared Services Org replicated to Tenant A and Tenant B (multicast scenario).

  2. Service Order Distribution
    Scenario: Service orders created in ESM for global operations need to be routed to the correct backend for execution. 
    Logic: Use sales org, service org, or region attributes. 
    Example: Orders for APAC route to Tenant C; EMEA orders route to Tenant D.

  3. Multicast for Shared Asset Management
    Scenario: Functional location updates must be sent to multiple tenants managing shared assets. 
    Logic: Evaluate multiple condition groups and send updates to all applicable tenants. 
    Example: A shared plant replicated to both Tenant A and Tenant B for synchronized maintenance planning.

  4. HR Service Delivery Use Case
    Scenario: HR service requests (e.g., onboarding, payroll inquiries) in ESM need routing to the correct S/4HANA tenant in a shared services model. 
    Logic: Determine the communication system based on employee attributes like company code, location, or employment type. 
    Example: Onboarding request for Company Code 1010 → S/4HANA Tenant A; Contractor payroll inquiry → ERP Tenant C. 

 

Outbound Configurations Supporting System Determination* 

  • Replicate Registered Product to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Registered Product to SAP ERP 
  • Replicate Functional Location to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Business Partner Relationship to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Business Partner Relationship to SAP ERP 
  • Replicate Business Partner to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Business Partner to SAP ERP 

 Support for outbound configurations related to Opportunity, Quote, and Order will be available soon.  

 * As of 30.10.2025. List will be updated as support for more outbound configurations is added 

 

Watch: Configuring Outbound System Determinations

 

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2  SAP Service Cloud Version 2 SAP Field Service Management SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management

entry.title: SAP User Experience Update: What’s New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 comes with a whole host of user experience innovations and improvements.  Web access via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad has many useful improvements, as does SAP Mobile Start for mobile access. Joule gives conversational access to Private Cloud Edition using natural language, now also with analytical insights. There are additional collaboration capabilities, and many improvements in details: some towards providing a more consistent and integrated SAP Business Suite, some simply making a user’s life easier. Finally, design and UI technology is also advancing, with powerful AI support for developers now available.

This post covers:

  • UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite
  • Web access: My Home and SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Mobile access: SAP Mobile Start
  • Joule
  • Situation Handling news
  • AI-Assisted capabilities: outlook
  • New collaboration capabilities
  • UX improvements in details
  • UI adaptation improvements for key users
  • Design and Technology news

If you want to get an impression of how good SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, looks across all the main product areas, have a look at the online Product Tour.

Since this post covers what’s new, building on the previous 2023 release, you might want to have a look at the UX innovations which came with the Feature Pack Stacks 00, 01 and 02 of the 2023 release:

  • SAP User Experience Update: What’s New for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

For a full overview of what’s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the documentation (note that it includes features from the above 2023 FPS01 and FPS02 blog posts, as well as this one):

  • What’s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite

We aim to provide a consistent and integrated experience for all users of the SAP Business Suite, which means providing an entry point for users to access all the various SAP products within the suite, and ensuring that the user experience across these products is consistent, making it easy for users to use applications from different products.

Entry Points

Figure 1 shows our approach for providing a web and a native mobile entry point to the products of the suite, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. I’d like to highlight that Joule can also be seen as an entry point to access the entire suite, since our goal is to provide Joule wherever you are, be it in our web applications or native mobile apps. Using Joule, our goal is to allow users to query and perform actions on all the products and applications which they are authorized to use, simply using natural language. As you’ll see below, we are making good progress towards this goal.

Figure 1: Entry points providing an integrated workplace for accessing the SAP Business Suite. Alt Text: Image showing Joule on the left, “available web and mobile”, and on the right a diagram with boxes indicating that SAP Mobile Start, SAP Start, and SAP Build Work Zone provide central access to SAP, with three boxes below for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors and Other SAP Products.

Web Central Access

I have covered recent UX innovations in our web central entry points, such as SAP Start and SAP Build Work Zone, and central services such as SAP Task Center, in my recent cloud UX blog posts. Since these capabilities also apply to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well as SAP S/4HANA (except for SAP Start), I will not repeat them here, but rather refer you to them:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 What we will look at in this post in detail are UX innovations for local access from web or mobile, via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad, and via SAP Mobile Start. Each has a dedicated section further below.

Design Updates for Suite Consistency

To achieve consistency across the suite, we have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we’ll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence, we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 2. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry “All Spaces” at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the “Favourite App” eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder “Insights” for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar – need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case “S/4HANA Cloud” as you can see at the top of Figure 2. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (i.e. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments – in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature “/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE”.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 3 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the “Sign Out” option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 Figure 3: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group “Last Month”, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a “more” link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 3 fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, and provides simpler interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by “Today”, “Yesterday”, “Last Week”, “Last Month”. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 4 shows two examples – one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

Web Access: My Home and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The 2025 release brings a number of improvements in My Home, the start page in the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as some improvements in the launchpad itself (beyond the design updates mentioned above) – for users as well as for administrators.

My Home

Here is an overview of the enhancements with this release:

  • To-Dos:
    • Tasks: Enhanced workflow relevant information and in-place actions
    • Situations from both standard and extended framework- are displayed
  • Intelligent homepage experience to boost productivity (cloud only):

    • Intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards.
  • Improved user experience: 
    • Drag & drop is now enabled in the insights section, so you can directly rearrange your tiles and cards.

To-Dos Enhancements

The To-Dos task cards now offer action buttons, for example to approve or reject items. Often, this requires some key information about the item, for example the name of the product and the value for a purchase requisition. These details are now visualized directly in the task cards, as you can see in Figure 5, making the workflow more efficient.

To-Dos now also shows custom Situations, created using the extended Situation Handling framework, in addition to the standard situations delivered by SAP.

Intelligent Homepage Experience

Another useful new feature is AI recommendations for applications: as you can see in Figure 5 in the Apps section of My Home, a new tab Recommended has been introduced which uses AI to create a list of applications which are recommended to the user to add to their Favorites.

To help users get started with My Home, we provide intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards, so that when they first log on, the Insights Cards section is not blank, but rather has a number of pre-delivered cards relevant to the user’s role.

Manage News Application

I’m glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 6 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users or roles. SAP Fiori Launchpad

The launchpad provides more than just the spaces and pages for finding and starting apps: it provides the runtime shell in which all the applications run, and hence the updates mentioned above such as the new navigation, the new shell bar and user menu. It also controls navigation between apps, as well as settings such as which theme to apply. Here are some additional improvements with the 2025 release. 

Automatic high-contrast and dark-mode detection, also for custom themes

Users can define on their front-end device’s operating system whether applications should appear in a light mode or a dark mode, or a high-contrast mode. Now these settings are taken into account also for custom themes, in addition to SAP visual themes.

Technically this is done by the launchpad supporting theme sets, which is a group of themes of the same family with different flavors – such as the Horizon theme, with a light and dark version along with high contrast black and high contrast white versions. Customers can create their own theme sets using the UI theme designer. Have a look at the documentation:

  • Managing Your Settings (see the setting Appearance).

Hiding empty pages and spaces

The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user’s authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty. Find out more here:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad: Hiding empty spaces and pages.

Improved About Dialog for Application Information

We have simplified the about screen, organizing it into separate tabs for Application, System and Environment information, so that there is a clear separation between the different types of information – see it in action in Figure 7:

Figure 7: New About dialog. Alt Text: A short video showing the list view of the Manage Sales Orders – Version 2 app. The user opens the user settings menu in the shell header bar, selects “about”, and a popover appears with the same design as the user settings, showing three separate tabs listed vertically on the left for “Application”, “System” and “Environment”, with “Application” the default. Application shows title and ID of the app, along with framework version; System shows the product, system and tenant name; Environment shows the client device type and user agent details.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps “Manage Launchpad Spaces” and “Manage Launchpad Pages” distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab “Customer-Created”, the others in the tab “Predefined”.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as “Customer-Created” in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became “Predefined” there, i.e. it was not listed under “Customer-Created” despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app “Manage Launchpad Pages”, the tabs are called “Pages” and “Page Templates”, as shown in Figure 8. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 8: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for “Pages” and “Page Templates”. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

Role-dependent Launchpad Configuration Parameters

We provide administrators a new option to apply launchpad settings role-based, so that different roles can have different settings being applied. This can be helpful if a specific group of users need different settings, for example if you want to gradually introduce Spaces and Pages, you no longer have to switch it on for all users. Find out more, and further examples, in the documentation:

  • Setting Parameters per Profile
