Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP’s cloud products, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access them and providing a nice flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we’ll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations in the web and mobile, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Customer specific skills and agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 12: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule “Show me sales commission by agend for model bike sales”, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 12, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 12 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as “What is the total revenue for Q1?” or “Show me sales by region in 2025”.
  • Comparative analysis, such as “Compare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?”
  • Time series analysis, such as “Show me sales by month” or “Show the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months”.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as “Show me top 5 sales by store” or “List the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales”.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 13 shows what this looks like.

Figure 13: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking “How many languages does Joule support”. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with “Joule currently supports eleven language officially” and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document “Joule Multi Language Support” is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button “+ New Conversation” at the top, followed by a section “Active” with two conversations and a section “Expired” with four. The bottom contains a link to “Settings” and on to “AI Notice”.

 You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on “New Conversation”. The old conversation will be listed in the “Active” section, as you can see in Figure 13. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the “Expired” section, as shown in Figure 13. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 14.

Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren’t Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well… the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly or embedded within applications.

Intelligent Situation Handling news

Intelligent Situation Handling speeds up the resolution of critical business situations by automatically and hence proactively alerting users about urgent issues, proposing follow-up actions, letting you monitor situations, and automating the resolution by using business rules.

If you’re not familiar with Intelligent Situation Handling, I recommend that you watch the introductory video and read the “Get started” blog posts on the SAP Community topic page:

  • Intelligent Situation Handling topic page.

 With the 2025 release, SAP provides nine new situation templates in the areas of finance, public sector, service, sourcing and procurement, and supply chain:

  • New use cases for Situation Handling.

 For the full list of available templates provided by SAP, look here:

  • Use Cases for Situation Handling.

New Situation Handling Framework Capabilities

Already with the 2023 release we made it possible for partners and customers to create their own situation objects with ABAP Development Tooling (ADT) via developer extensibility. This becomes even more powerful with the 2025 release, with the extended framework supporting the collection of data context, support for custom objects in your own use cases, and support for the standard translation option. Let’s have a look at these in a bit more detail.

Data Context supported by the Extended Framework

The data context is business data from business objects involved in a situation instance that can be collected, distributed, and used for advanced analytics – for example using the Monitor Situations – Extended app. If enabled in a situation type, data context is collected when a situation instance is created, updated, or completed. For example, If you use the situation template Quantity Deficit in Supplier's Delivery to inform specific members in your purchasing organization about a deficit in the quantity of materials to be delivered by the supplier, you'll get, for example, the material, plant, or supplier as part of the data context.

With the 2025 release, every extended object-based situation template supports data context. You can activate it in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app. Doing so results in an event being triggered that includes the data context every time a situation instance is created, updated or completed. For more information, look at the documentation:

  • Data Context (documentation).
  • Data Context in the What’s New documentation.

Custom Object Types Supported

You can now use custom object types and object node types, that you have created with the ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT), in situation objects in the Manage Situation Objects app as well as in ADT. Until now, you could only use those delivered by SAP. Hence you have far more flexibility in supporting your own Situation Handling use cases.

Translation with Standard Function Supported

With this feature, you can use the standard function for translating texts included in situation objects, situation scenarios, and situation types. This means that you now can use the Maintain Translations app, so that all your translation work can be done in a consistent way now. Find out more in the documentation:

  • Translate Texts from Situation Objects, Situation Scenarios, and Situation Types.

New Collaboration Capabilities

Collaborative Draft

Some selected applications support collaborative draft handling of business objects. This means that more than one user can edit a business object, such as a payment advice, at the same time, and see changes made by others before the object is finally saved.

 Within the object page, the object header shows the avatars of those who are editing; you also get the avatar shown next to fields which they are editing. Also, we have extended the grid table to indicate which entries are currently in a draft state, as well as showing those currently being edited by someone else (see Figure 16); this is also available in the responsive tables.

 You can invite other users to join you in working on an object, as you can also see in Figure 16.

On the bottom left you can see the new indicators in grid tables. Alt Text: three screenshots are shown as described, the names of the colleagues editing are shown as pop-overs.

 Collaborative draft utilizes the latest SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 technology.

UX Improvements in Details

As I never tire of saying: the details matter if you want to provide a great UX! We continue to work on these details, which can often result in higher satisfaction for users. With the 2025 release, we bring you a large number of improvements, as outlined in the following subsections. Note that we have four interesting ones related to working with tables towards the end of this section.

New Options for Filtering Dates (Semantic Date Range)

We have two new features here:

  • We now offer the semantic date range also for selecting dates in the table settings dialog, if you want to define a specific filter on a given field in the table. (Note that the table settings dialog allows you to define filters on all the fields in the table, irrespective of which fields appear in the filter bar at the top of the screen).
  • I’m pleased to say that, on request of many users, we now provide the option to define filters on date fields for the “Last X days/weeks/months/… to date” as well as the “Next X days/weeks/months/… to date”, where users can specify the number “X”.

An example of how tricky such seemingly simple things can be: if, on December 11th, you choose “Last 2 months to date”, do you mean the period from November 1st to December 11th, which would be up to the current date but not a full two months, or do you mean “the last two full months”, i.e. October 1st to November 30th? Since both make sense, the selection screen gives users the option to choose, with the default being the “full month” case, described as “exclude current period”, as you can see in Figure 20.

Column Size Persisted in Flexible Column Layout

When users open up an application which uses the Flexible Column Layout, it will now remember where the user had placed the separator last time, rather than putting it in the default position. Figure 21 shows an example where at the top you see the default position, and below you see the separator moved to the right slightly, so that all the text is visible in the table on the left. Next time the app is opened, the separator will open in the same place.

Figure 21: Flexible Column Layout now remembers the previously used column width. The image at the top shows the default column width, the image below shows the last column width the user chose. Alt Text: two images of Manage Cost Centers application is shown, the upper one has the separator bar between the list on the left and the details on the right further to the left than the image on the right.

All Data Dictionary Help Texts Available to Users

This feature was requested by many customers, and I am happy to announce that it is now available: all the help texts for individual fields which are stored in the back-end data dictionary are now available to users using the built-in help, powered by SAP Companion. In other words, users of SAP Fiori apps have access to the same help texts as were shown with the classic UIs such as SAP GUI. You can see an example in Figure 22.

Figure 22: Data Dictionary help texts now available in SAP Fiori apps. Alt Text: The Manage Purchase Contracts screen is shown, with question marks next to all fields and column headers. On the right the Help Topics are listed, with the Purchase Contract Number selected. Next to the corresponding column header a popover shows the definition text.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse – but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting “Keyboard Shortcuts” in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 23 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 24.

Figure 23: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Generic Keyboard Interactions”.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app “Manage Journal Entries” with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, “Global Shortcuts” and “Journal Entries (43,854)”. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using “Cmd + D” to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time – magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The “Threshold” determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the “Scroll Threshold” determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “Configure Table” with two new fields “Threshold”, being edited with the value 3000, and “Scroll Threshold”, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or “Show more per row” State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if “show more per row” was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry “1710 (BestRun US)”, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is “BestRun US”. In the popover “Sort By” section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over “Column Settings” with two sections “Sort By” and “Group By”. The “Sort By” section has two lines, “Company Code” and “Company Name”, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing “no sorting”, “ascending”, “descending”.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over “View Settings” containing tabs “Columns”, “Sort”, “Filter”, and a pop-over “Filters” with two options “Hide descriptions” (selected) and “Hide Unselected” (deselected) . “Columns” is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is “Company Code”, followed by “Created On” – i.e. the description column “Company Name” is not listed next to the “Company Code”.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what’s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What’s New Viewer:

  • What’s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The “Adapt UI” option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example “1710 (BestRun US)” as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example “US Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)” as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the “Export to Excel”, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called “Configure Table” filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as “Enable Table Export”, “Frozen Column Count” with a field for entering the number, “Sorting”, “Columns” etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits – now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP’s UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, … for Android, … for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1 and Q3 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 31 shows examples. 

Figure 31: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don’t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging – so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I’m looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd – Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: Navigating Oman’s Regulatory Evolution with SAP ERP HCM Localization
entry.content:
In today’s rapidly changing regulatory landscape, localization is more than a technical requirement - it’s a strategic enabler. SAP’s localization framework enables enterprises to remain compliant with country-specific mandates while driving operational efficiency and business continuity.

For Oman, this means aligning with recent key reforms such as the Social Protection Fund (SPF) and preparing for the anticipated introduction of Personal Income Tax (PIT).

Oman Localization Scope

SAP ERP HCM offers tailored localization features for Oman, supporting legal reporting, payroll processing, and statutory compliance. These features are designed to help businesses navigate regulatory changes with agility and confidence.

Key Features

  • Social Protection Fund (SPF): The establishment of Oman’s Social Protection Fund marks a major milestone in social reform. It brings multiple social security programs under one framework to strengthen coverage and sustainability. Implementation started on January 1, 2024, with phased timelines extending to 2028 for certain schemes. SAP ERP HCM supports this transformation by enabling the configuration and processing of Social Insurance schemes in line with legal requirements. For detailed documentation and configuration guidance, visit the SAP Help Portal.

 

  • Leaves and Absences: The system supports both standard and Oman-specific leave types; It also provides flexible capabilities for absence distribution, advance leave payments, provisioning, and granting.
  • Ticket Benefit: The solution provides the flexibility to implement benefits such as leave passage according to business needs. It allows defining eligibility, frequency, and cost parameters, integrated with payroll for accurate processing.
  • End-of-Service (EOS): The Oman local version allows the provisioning and calculation of end-of-service gratuity for employees in line with the law. The OMEOS feature evaluates eligibility based on termination reasons and ensures accurate settlements.
  • Wage Protection System (WPS): Compliance with Oman’s WPS is supported through the Oman WPS File Generation Report (HOMWPSF0), generating payment and bank details in the required format.

For detailed configuration guidance, please check out the SAP Help Portal.

Looking Ahead: Oman Personal Income Tax Introduction

Oman has officially introduced a Personal Income Tax Law, marking a historic fiscal shift in the Gulf region. Effective January 1, 2028, a 5% tax will apply to annual income exceeding OMR 42,000. This initiative supports Oman Vision 2040, which aims to diversify the economy and enhance fiscal sustainability.

SAP continues to monitor the progress of this reform and plans to include relevant functionalities - such as payroll tax calculation and reporting - as part of its future roadmap.

Stay Informed: Key Resources for Oman Localization

As Oman continues to modernize its social and fiscal systems, SAP remains committed to delivering timely and relevant updates. Stay connected and informed through the following resources:

  • Join SAP Build Work Zone: Access curated localization content, announcements, and collaboration spaces.
  • Explore the SAP Localization Community: Engage with peers and SAP experts and subscribe to the Localization tag for the latest updates.
  • Subscribe to SAP Regulatory Change Manager: Stay up to date with legal changes and their impact on SAP solutions.

Feel free to share your thoughts or questions below. We would love to hear from you.

entry.title: Re: Error during processing of Inbound Bank Message(SAP_C...
entry.content:
Hello @poornaprakashk 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Journal Entry - Clearing Confirmation (Asynchronous), Payment Batch Status Check

Payment Batch Configurations and Payment Status Reports SAP BCM - S4HANA

APIs for Invoice Management

In summary, based on the details you provided, the BCM inbound failure error occurs because you seem to have missed the standard SAP MessageHeader. It seems you did not include it in the SOAP envelope. Ensure you add it whilst ensuring your sender/recipient IDS match the Communication Arrangement configuration.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: What's New SAP Asset Performance Management 2510
entry.content:
With SAP Asset Performance Management 2510, we've enabled Streaming Analytics in the embedded IoT platform (currently available through the Early Adopter Care program), enabling incoming data points to be evaluated in real time. Additionally, Trigger Rules ensure relevant events automatically generate maintenance actions. For scheduled rules, the new configurable delay/offset guarantees that all data is considered before evaluation, reducing missed insights and improving reliability. On top of that, extended characteristic types - including numeric, date, currency, and time - make strategy-based class assignments more flexible. 

 

Contents

Near Real-Time Insights with Streaming Analytics and Trigger Rules in the Embedded IoT Platform
Configure Rule Offset for Data Ingestion Delays
Extended Characteristic Types for Strategy-Based Class Assignments
Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

Near Real-Time Insights with Streaming Analytics and Trigger Rules in the Embedded IoT Platform

We have enabled Streaming Analytics in the embedded IoT platform,  helping you to process every incoming data point in real time — enabling additional rules-based use cases. It is currently available through the  Early Adopter Care program.

Alongside this, a new Trigger Rule integration links Streaming Analytics directly to SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), ensuring that real-time insights can automatically generate maintenance actions. Together, these innovations bridge the gap between live IoT data and asset management processes.

Entry point to Streaming Analytics app in the Embedded IoT Platform

Why Streaming Analytics?

Traditional APM rules analyze data in batches, identifying trends and deviations over time. This is ideal for long-term monitoring, but sometimes you need to respond immediately.

That’s where Streaming Analytics comes in. It evaluates each data point the moment it enters the system, allowing you to:

  • Detect threshold violations in real time.
  • Preprocess data by rounding or smoothing sensor values.
  • Derive new indicators to enrich your asset model.
  • Convert machine alarms into APM alerts when needed.

So in a nutshell the difference is:

  • APM rules analyze data in batches—over hours or days—to find trends or deviations.
  • Streaming analytics evaluates each data point as it arrives, triggering instant actions such as alerts or maintenance tasks.

How It Works

Using the Analytics Builder in the embedded IoT platform, you can define streaming rules in a low-code environment. 

For example, you might create a rule that rounds temperature readings, defines a Preprocessed Temperature value, and triggers an alert when a threshold is exceeded.

The preprocessed values appear as new time-series data in the IoT device model and can be mapped to APM indicators, ensuring both raw and processed data are available for analysis and condition-based monitoring.

Example of IoT device model settings - preprocessed measurement values

Trigger Rule Integration with APM Rules

To ensure real-time insights lead to immediate action, a custom Trigger Rule output connects Streaming Analytics results with APM standard rules.

When a Streaming Analytics model detects a defined condition, the Trigger Rule can automatically activate a corresponding APM rule. That APM rule then performs its configured action — such as creating an alert, generating a maintenance demand, or updating an asset’s condition status.

This integration keeps APM and IoT environments synchronized, so that events detected in near real time are instantly reflected in the asset management process.

Together, Streaming Analytics and Trigger Rules enable a continuous feedback loop between data detection, decision, and action:

  1. The IoT platform processes incoming data points in near real time.
  2. Streaming Analytics detects relevant events.
  3. Trigger Rules ensure those events automatically lead to actions in APM.

This combination gives you a faster and more connected approach to managing asset performance — from sensor to action.

Watch this detailed demo to see how it works:

Click to watch video

For detailed information on Streaming Analytics application and analytics builder, refer to the SAP Help Portal and check out the official documentation from the Embedded IoT platform provider.

  • Streaming Analytics
  • Analytics Builder

 

Configure Rule Offset for Data Ingestion Delays

In condition monitoring, timing critical. For example, if rules run before all data has arrived, evaluations can be incomplete — leading to missed insights or unreliable alerts. We've therefore introduced a configurable offset for scheduled rules, designed to ensure every data point counts.

With this enhancement, rules execute after the expected data arrival, based on the known ingestion pattern of each data source. Whether data comes through APIs with a 90-minute delay or through daily file uploads, you can now define an offset that aligns rule execution with real data availability.

This results in:

  • Complete and accurate evaluation of all data points
  • Reliable condition monitoring – each point is evaluated once, no duplication or omissions
  • Flexible and customer-specific configuration for API- or file-based ingestion
  • Reduced operational risk through trusted, automated alerts and notifications

By aligning rule execution with the know data ingestion timing, you can have more confidence in your insights and automated monitoring. For more information see the SAP Help Portal Triggering a Rule.

Example of how to configure the rule offset

Watch this video for more details:

Watch the video

 

Extended Characteristic Types for Strategy-Based Class Assignments

Previously, APM only supported characteristic type Char with allowed values, limiting the ability to capture and utilize different types of data for technical objects. This made it harder for customers to accurately identify relevant object values and take timely maintenance actions. 

We now include Numeric, Date, Currency, and Time data type characteristics. These new characteristic types can be used when creating strategy-based class assignments, allowing more comprehensive and flexible data capture for technical objects.

Customers can now easily identify the associated values of technical objects across multiple data types and initiate the required maintenance more efficiently, improving asset management accuracy and operational reliability.

Example of new characteristic types for strategy assessment for classes

 

New OData APIs

To enhance the API offerings, GraphQL APIs Strategy Assessment for Classes and Failure Data Assessments will be deprecated as of October 21, 2026. We encourage you to migrate to the new Failure Data Assessment OData API that will cater to both strategy assessment for classes and RCM assessments.

For more information, refer to SAP Note 3603407 and APIs for Asset Reliability Engineering.

 

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition brings deeper integration with SAP Asset Performance Management (APM). APM recommendations, indicators, and assessments are now visible directly in the Find Technical Objects app, together with risk and criticality information. In addition, APM failure data relationships can now be used to select Failure Modes and Failure Effects during maintenance processes, ensuring the right task lists are assigned and actions are aligned with historical recommendations.

For full details, read Fernanda Rodrigues' blog Asset Management in SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Release and explore Fernanda's other blogs too.

 

Stay Informed and Get Involved

  • Find out what's up and coming in the SAP Road Map Explorer.
  • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
  • Send us your improvement requests. Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.
  • Check the APM link collection. 

Let us know what you think about these new features - leave us a comment below or ask a question! 

See you soon for the 2511 update!
